body:
Leudinus

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
(Redirected from Leudinus Bodo )
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Leudinus Bodo [1] was a seventh-century bishop of Toul , successor to Eborinus , or Elbonirus. [2] He was a Benedictine . [3] He occurs in hagiographies. His feast day is Sept. 11. [4]

He is traditionally known as the founder of Bodonis Monasterium (the monastery of Bodo), later called Bon-Moutier (Bonmoutier, Bon Moustiers). [5] Bonmoutier is in the modern Val-et-Châtillon , Vosges .

He is said to have been born around 625, in Bassigny , to Gundoin and Saratrude of the Etichonids , a family of the Austrasian nobility. His sister was Saint Salaberge , who founded the monastery at Laon . [6] He founded also the Abbey of Étival (Stivagium, Abbaye Saint-Pierre d'Étival [7] ), [8] dated to 663 [9] and the Abbey of Othonville , and died around 678. [10]

References [ edit ]

  • Paul Burns (2000), Butler's Lives of the Saints , p. 101.

Notes [ edit ]

  1. ^ Leudovinus, Leudvinus, Leudvin, Leudin, Lendin, Saint Bodo, Saint Bodon.
  2. ^ http://www.gourment.chez-alice.fr/evequesdetoul.htm
  3. ^ OSB. Saints of the Order of Saint Benedict. 1/4
  4. ^ http://www.amisaintcolomban.org/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/30_Bodo_Leudin2.pdf
  5. ^ "Page 3 - Le diocèse de Saint-Dié" . Archived from the original on 2007-07-12 . Retrieved 2011-12-07 .
  6. ^ Catholic Encyclopedia: Nancy
  7. ^ fr:Abbaye Saint-Pierre d'Étival
  8. ^ Now Étival-Clairefontaine , Vosges; "Archived copy" . Archived from the original on 2007-10-10 . Retrieved 2007-10-31 . CS1 maint: archived copy as title ( link ) , [1] Archived 2008-03-16 at the Wayback Machine .
  9. ^ "Archived copy" . Archived from the original on 2007-12-24 . Retrieved 2007-10-31 . CS1 maint: archived copy as title ( link )
  10. ^ [2] , in French.

[2] He was a Benedictine . [3] He occurs in hagiographies.  His feast day is Sept. 11. [4] He is traditionally known as the founder of Bodonis Monasterium (the monastery of Bodo), later called Bon-Moutier (Bonmoutier, Bon Moustiers). [5] Bonmoutier is in the modern Val-et-Châtillon , Vosges . He is said to have been born around 625, in Bassigny , to Gundoin and Saratrude of the Etichonids , a family of the Austrasian nobility. His sister was Saint Salaberge , who founded the monastery at Laon . [6] He founded also the Abbey of Étival (Stivagium, Abbaye Saint-Pierre d'Étival [7] ), [8] dated to 663 [9] and the Abbey of Othonville , and died around 678.
